item.title: India Built the World’s Back Office. A.I. Is Starting to Shrink It.
item.description: Artificial intelligence promises to automate the white-collar work that made India a tech powerhouse. The country is racing to adapt before it’s too late.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers, Paul Mozur and Saumya Khandelwal
item.media:description: Hunar.AI is offering companies bespoke A.I. voice agents that steer job applicants through virtually every step of the hiring process.

item.title: With a New Nigeria Refinery, Africa’s Richest Man Wants ‘to Rescue the Country’
item.description: Aliko Dangote, Africa’s richest man, has an ambitious vision for the continent’s most populous nation, but hurdles stand in his way.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.media:credit: Victor Adewale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aliko Dangote at home in Lagos, Nigeria, last month.

item.title: Germany’s Oil and Gas Output Is Dwindling as Prices Rise
item.description: Natural gas production in Germany has fallen about 80 percent in the past two decades even as the country seeks to replace flows from Russia.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed and Maximilian Mann
item.media:description: The Gas Nord production facility of Harbour Energy Germany in Langwedel-Holtebüttel.

item.title: 32.6 Million Watched Trump’s State of the Union Address, Nielsen Says
item.description: The audience was roughly on par with former President Biden’s final State of the Union address in 2024.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Congressional staff members watching President Trump’s State of the Union address at the Capitol on Tuesday.

item.title: Block Cuts 40% of Its Work Force Because of Its Embrace of A.I.
item.description: About 4,000 workers will lose their jobs as the payments company does more work with new artificial intelligence tools, its top executive said.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha
item.media:credit: Koshiro K/Alamy
item.media:description: Jack Dorsey, Block’s top executive, attributed job cuts to his company’s embrace of A.I.

item.title: Netflix Backs Out of Bid for Warner Bros., Paving Way for Paramount Takeover
item.description: The move was a stunning development in the long-running corporate battle for the storied media giant.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch, Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paramount Pictures in Hollywood.

item.title: Oliver Grant, a Business Architect of the Wu-Tang Clan, Dies
item.description: He was behind the scenes with Wu-Tang Clan, the New York rap group, since its founding and helped expand its reach with a fashion line.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Efren Landaos/SOPA Images/LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Oliver Grant at the premiere of the “Wu-Tang: An American Saga” television series in New York City in 2019.

item.title: FedEx Says It Could Return Tariff Refunds to Customers
item.description: The company sued the administration days after the Supreme Court ruled against the president’s duties.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: FedEx has pledged to return money to shippers and customers if a federal court orders the Trump administration to refund tariffs it charged the company.

item.title: U.S. Mortgage Rates Fall Below 6% for First Time in Years
item.description: The evidence is patchy on whether lower rates have meaningfully spurred more activity, as the Trump administration floats measures it says will make housing more affordable.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Schmidt
item.category: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)
item.media:credit: Carlos Bernate for The New York Times

item.title: Why Estrogen Patches For Menopause Are So Hard to Find
item.description: Changing attitudes around menopause treatment have driven up demand for hormone therapy.
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.media:credit: Associated Press

item.title: They Helped Women Fight Online Abuse. They Were Barred From the U.S.
item.description: The founders of HateAid, a German human-rights group that helps victims of online attacks, were accused by the Trump administration of being part of a “global censorship-industrial complex.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Patrick Junker
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna-Lena von Hodenberg, left, and Josephine Ballon, right, of the organization HateAid. The group provides legal support for victims of digital violence and engages in policy advocacy aimed at strengthening accountability for major online platforms.

item.title: How a Close Associate of Epstein’s Found Career Redemption in Japan
item.description: Top Japanese officials are backing a tech and entrepreneurship initiative led by Joichi Ito, whose involvement with Jeffrey Epstein may endanger efforts to get the project off the ground.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Hisako Ueno

item.title: He Hopes to Turn the Island of Nevis Into a Libertarian Paradise, With Crypto
item.description: A Bitcoin baron wants to build a libertarian paradise on the island of Nevis. Democracy is getting in the way.
item.dc:creator: Atossa Araxia Abrahamian
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olivier Janssens, propelled by his cryptocurrency fortune, wants to build an enclave where residents would have special rights on Nevis.

item.title: Why Nvidia’s Big Profits Aren’t Lifting Markets
item.description: The chip giant at the center of the artificial intelligence boom again beat expectations. But it didn’t overcome investor jitters.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly and Brian O’Keefe
item.media:credit: Mikayla Whitmore for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jensen Huang’s Nvidia just blew away Wall Street estimates. But to investors’ chagrin, that performance has failed to move the market.

item.title: Revel, a Maker of Software for Running Hardware, Raises $150 Million
item.description: The start-up, founded by a former top SpaceX engineer, promises to help companies reduce their testing times and optimize systems.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced

item.title: World Economic Forum Chief Resigns Over Epstein Ties
item.description: Borge Brende, a former foreign minister of Norway, had maintained contact with the convicted sex offender.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Fabrice Coffrini/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Borge Brende led the World Economic Forum, which runs an annual summit in Davos, Switzerland, for more than eight years.

item.title: Z? Zo? Mam? Mayor Zohran Mamdani is a Man of Many Nicknames.
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani has been given a bevy of nicknames by New York City’s tabloid newspapers and political class. Which will stick?
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum and Eliza Shapiro
item.media:credit: Mark Harris

item.title: New A.C.A. Plans Could Increase Family Deductibles to $31,000
item.description: The Trump administration is proposing Obamacare plans that it says will lower health insurance premiums. But critics warn they would make care unaffordable.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Mehmet Oz, who oversees Medicare and Medicaid, promoted new proposals that he said would lower costs. Critics fear the options will increase medical bills and drive people out of insurance plans.

item.title: A.I. Dating Apps Complicate China’s Efforts to Boost Birthrate
item.description: As China grapples with a shrinking population and historically low birthrate, people are finding romance with chatbots instead.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Murphy Zhao and Meaghan Tobin
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Kalshi Accuses a ‘MrBeast’ Employee of Insider Trading
item.description: The prediction-market platform said it had reported the employee to federal regulators. The show’s parent company said it had “no tolerance for this behavior.”
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: For America’s 250th, Should the Coin of Trump’s Realm Be Gold?
item.description: A federally appointed committee is pushing back on plans to mint gold currency depicting President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Dan Barry

item.title: Trump Proposed a New Retirement Plan for With Up to a $1,000 Match. What to Know.
item.description: An existing law could help create new retirement savings plans for people who lack them. But there may be income restrictions on any match.
item.dc:creator: Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: A proposal by President Trump during his State of the Union address could benefit tens of millions of workers who do not have access to workplace retirement plans.

item.title: Businesses Push for Tariff Refunds as Trump Aides Hint at Fight to Come
item.description: By the president’s own admission, it could be years before the matter is settled, even though the administration previously indicated it would pay.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: Some large companies, including FedEx, have filed lawsuits seeking to recover the money paid in tariffs under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act.

item.title: Blaming Tariffs, Aston Martin Will Trim 20% of Its Work Force
item.description: The luxury automaker said losses for 2025 had increased from the year before, as tariffs and geopolitical uncertainty took a toll on its operations.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Schmidt

item.title: What Trump Did (and Didn’t) Say in the State of the Union Speech
item.description: The president boasted about a strong economy in his State of the Union address. But he spent less time on a potential weakness, affordability.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Ian Mount and Benjamin Weiser
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump sought to paint a glossy picture of the U.S. economy in his State of the Union address, which critics said belied reality.

item.title: Bleak Research Report Stokes A.I. Debate on Wall St.
item.description: In a widely circulated note, Citrini Research painted a dire picture of job losses and stock market sell-offs, though many analysts and economists questioned its conclusions.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York Stock Exchange, where investors have been wrestling with questions about the future impact of artificial intelligence.

item.title: From the French Riviera to Kyoto, Japan, 5 New Luxury Hotels
item.description: From palatial to contemporary to luxuriously rustic, this collection of new resorts and inns offers spas, private gardens, fine restaurants and exquisite settings.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Rosenbloom

item.title: Abu Dhabi’s State Oil Company Looks Beyond Oil
item.description: Having reshaped the company, Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber wants to expand internationally, particularly in natural gas, chemicals and renewables.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed and Natalie Naccache
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber has helped put ADNOC, Abu Dhabi’s state oil company, on the map as a global deal maker.

item.title: Court Rules Against Justice Dept. Search of Reporter’s Computers
item.description: The judge said the court itself would search the devices, which were seized from a Washington Post reporter’s home last month.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: The courthouse for the Eastern District of Virginia in Alexandria, where a judge rejected an “unsupervised, wholesale” search by the federal government.

item.title: Wayve, an A.I. Driverless Car Start-Up in Europe, Raises $1.2 Billion
item.description: The London-based company is building a system that uses artificial intelligence to power autonomous vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun, via Getty Images
item.media:description: New funding values Wayve at $8.6 billion.

item.title: Pentagon Gives Anthropic an Ultimatum Over the Company’s A.I. Model
item.description: Anthropic insists on limits on how its technology is used and could be labeled a supply chain risk if it fails to accept the military’s demands.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth summoned the chief executive of Anthropic to Washington for a meeting on Tuesday.

item.title: Paramount Raises Its Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: Warner Bros. Discovery said Paramount’s new offer of $31 a share could lead to a “superior proposal” to the deal it signed with Netflix.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paramount previously offered $30 a share to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery.

item.title: Senator Blumenthal Opens Inquiry Into Iran Transactions on Binance
item.description: Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut sent a letter to Binance asking about the flow of $1.7 billion from accounts on the crypto exchange to Iranian entities.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Michael Forsythe
item.category: Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross for The New York Times
item.media:description: In a letter to Binance, Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut asked for records about the company’s dealings with two Hong Kong entities identified by the exchange’s investigators as the origin of the transfers to Iran.

item.title: House Narrowly Rejects Air Safety Bill After Pentagon Opposition
item.description: A move to swiftly pass the bill failed by a single vote. It would have required aircraft to carry technology that officials said might have prevented a midair collision near Washington last year.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.category: Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bill’s failure upends the debate around how to respond to last year’s fatal crash between a military helicopter and a commercial jet over the Potomac River.

item.title: Averted Midair Collision Shows Importance of Air Safety Act, Backers Say
item.description: The legislation’s advocates say a close call between two private planes near Teterboro, N.J., on Feb. 13 underscored how collision prevention technology could save lives.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly and Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Gary Hershorn/Getty Images
item.media:description: A Learjet corporate aircraft carrying eight people to Teterboro Airport in New Jersey was forced to to descend quickly to avoid a midair collision on Feb. 13.

item.title: Home Depot Says Homeowners Are Weary From Economic Pressures
item.description: The retailer said same-store sales were nearly flat as homeowners shied away from big-ticket projects amid worries about housing costs and the job market.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin
item.media:credit: Daniel Cole/Reuters
item.media:description: Home Depot has seen “significantly reduced demand for projects and other purchases associated with buying and selling a home,” its chief financial officer said.

item.title: Trump’s New Tariffs Could Face Legal Challenges
item.description: Critics are questioning the legality of the provision President Trump has used to replace his previous slate of tariffs, raising the prospect of yet another legal battle.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: As the president takes steps to resurrect his tariffs, his chief legal foes are mulling their own options.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Are Adding Steel Mill Jobs, and Crushing American Factories
item.description: Tariffs unaffected by President Trump’s Supreme Court loss are adding costs for many U.S. manufacturers that use steel, limiting exports and jeopardizing jobs.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:credit: Bryan Birks for The New York Times
item.media:description: News that the Granite City Steel factory in Granite City, Ill., was rehiring laid-off steel workers was hailed as a sign of industrial revival.

item.title: Trump Officials Seek to ‘Reimagine’ Unemployment Benefits, Targeting Fraud
item.description: Federal officials are subjecting some states to higher scrutiny in an antifraud campaign, as the president rails against California and states led by Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s efforts to make broad changes to unemployment insurance have raised concerns among groups that support the aid.

item.title: Supreme Court Sides With Couple in Case Involving Baby Food Sold at Whole Foods
item.description: The court agreed to revive a lawsuit by a Texas couple who claimed that tainted baby food purchased at Whole Foods had sickened their young son.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Texas couple sued a baby food manufacturer and the grocery chain Whole Foods, arguing that food bought at the store had harmed their young son.

item.title: More Than Half of Teens Use Chatbots for Schoolwork, Survey Finds
item.description: A new study from the Pew Research Center finds teenagers think chatbot-assisted cheating has become “a regular feature of student life.”
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Ysa Pérez for The New York Times

item.title: Storm Leads to a First for The Boston Globe: A Day Without a Paper
item.description: The company said the blizzard had made it too treacherous for workers to make it to the printing press on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: John Tlumacki/The Boston Globe, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Boston Globe’s printing press in Taunton, Mass., in 2017.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Go Into Effect at 10 Percent, Not 15
item.description: The change surprised executives and foreign leaders, who had been expecting the 15 percent rate the president announced on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shipping containers in Miami last year. Within hours of the Supreme Court ruling on Friday, President Trump said he would impose a 10 percent tariff globally to replace the ones the court had ruled against.

item.title: Corporate America’s Growing Quest for Tariff Refunds
item.description: Thousands of companies are expected to follow FedEx in suing the government to recoup levy payments, after the Supreme Court overturned the tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly and Brian O’Keefe
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: FedEx is the latest, and one of the most prominent, companies to sue for a “full refund” of tariffs.

item.title: Paramount Revises Its Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: If Warner Bros. deems Paramount’s latest bid superior, Netflix would have four days to make a counteroffer.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Ricardo Nagaoka for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paramount had until the end of Monday to submit its best and final offer for Warner Bros. Discovery, which previously announced a deal with Netflix.

item.title: Racing to Catch Up With Nvidia, AMD Signs Chips-for-Stock Deal With Meta
item.description: The multibillion-dollar deal is AMD’s latest move to catch up to Nvidia in the lucrative world of selling artificial intelligence chips.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle and Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Steve Marcus/Reuters
item.media:description: Lisa Su, AMD’s chief executive, has been trying to break into a market for A.I. chips that has been dominated by Nvidia.

item.title: I.R.S. Tactics Against Meta Open a New Front in the Corporate Tax Fight
item.description: The agency is using real-world profit data to challenge how big companies value offshore intellectual property.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Drucker
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Washington headquarters of the Internal Revenue Service, which says Meta owes nearly $16 billion in back taxes and penalties.

item.title: The Looming Taiwan Chip Disaster That Silicon Valley Has Long Ignored
item.description: If China invades Taiwan and cuts off its chip exports to American companies, the tech industry and the U.S. economy would be crippled.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Ben Jones; Source Photographs by Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times; Loren Elliott for The New York Times; Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
